description: Get "Extension Manager", aka "gnome-shell-extension-manager" instead: that one actually lets you install extensions.

summary: Just switch the Source to Flatpack

description:
Why the default source option should be flathub, which means
2 Gb data download for an application that is merely a few hundred kilobytes (if I download it from the official fedora repos)?

I can understand the technical reason why even the smallest application as a flatpak can be so large but in this, specific, case what is the benefit? Extensions are very much tied to Gnome. Why should I flatpak an older Extension application, when there is a risk under a newer Gnome environment not working at all?
why is it so huge?
This is exactly what I needed. I honestly don't know why Gnome 40 is like this but with these tweaks it feels great
It's much smaller

Does what it says on the tin. My only complaint is that it relies largely on the developers of each individual extension to implement coherent error messages. Many extensions that do not work on a particular version of GNOME or have some other compatibility issue do not provide an understandable error message to the user. Perhaps some sort of error detection framework that could provide some high level info about the issue would be helpful?

description:
It's better to combine Extension Manager app along with new Themes option.

Example:-
Explore	Installed	Updates	[Extensions]	[Themes]


And also please add a repository management tool.

Example:-
Enabling repositories [Check]
Disabling repositories [Check]
Adding repositories [Needed]
Removing repositories [Needed]
Customizing repositories [Needed]
Multi-selection of repositories [Needed]
